M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Custody and parenting modifications are governed by M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, which authorizes the Court to modify prior judgments upon a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of minor children.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION OF CUSTODY ORDER (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20)

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters of custody and visitation under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, and M.G.L. c. 215, § 6.

Section 31 of M.G.L. c. 208.proposition: Section 31 of M.G.L. c. 208 explicitly places emphasis on the child’s safety and well-being when assessing parental cooperation in joint custody.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The standard for modification requires a showing of a “material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the previous judgment” and that modification would serve the best interests of the children.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns an initial custody determination and the required findings regarding domestic violence and its effect on the child, not the standard for a later *modification* of an existing custody judgment. Nowhere does the court articulate a requirement of a “material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the previous judgment” plus best interests as the governing standard. That modification standard comes from other Massachusetts cases, not from Custody of Vaughn.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Herbert v. Herbert, 303 Mass. 369 (1939).proposition: The standard for modification requires a showing of a “material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the previous judgment” and that modification would serve the best interests of the children.
Herbert v. Herbert, 303 Mass. 369 (1939).support_reasoning: This case concerns tort liability of a bankruptcy trustee/receiver and whether an action can be maintained against the trustee’s executrix after the trustee has been discharged. It does not involve domestic relations, child custody or support, nor does it discuss standards for modification of prior family law judgments or “material and substantial change in circumstances” or the best interests of children. The proposition is therefore unrelated to the holding or reasoning in this opinion.
Herbert v. Herbert, 303 Mass. 369 (1939).relevant_excerpt: The question to be decided is whether an action brought against a trustee for a debtor corporation appointed under § 77B, to recover damages for a tort alleged to have been committed while the trustee was operating the business of the debtor under an order of the bankruptcy court can still be prosecuted against his executrix after he has divested himself of all the assets and has been discharged by the court.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Where cooperation and mutual respect have broken down, modification to sole legal custody may be warranted.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses joint legal and physical custody, emphasizing that such arrangements require cooperation and communication, but the case is a removal/best-interests decision and does not order or even discuss a modification from joint to sole legal custody as a remedy when cooperation breaks down. The court affirms continued shared legal and physical custody and never articulates a rule that a breakdown in cooperation and mutual respect warrants modification to sole legal custody. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Although the General Laws state that there is no presumption ‘either in favor or against shared . . . custody at the time of trial on the merits,’ G. L. c. 208, § 31, such an arrangement is generally appropriate only if the parties demonstrate an ability and desire to cooperate amicably and communicate with one another to raise the children. … ‘[I]n order to be effective ‘joint custody requires ... a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions in a manner similar to the way married couples make decisions.’” (quoting Rolde v. Rolde).

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Where cooperation and mutual respect have broken down, modification to sole legal custody may be warranted.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss joint vs. sole legal custody, nor breakdown of parental cooperation or mutual respect as a ground for modifying custody. Instead, it reverses a custody award because the trial judge failed to apply and articulate the statutory best-interests criteria, emphasizing that custody must be based on the child’s welfare rather than parental misconduct or punishment. It therefore does not provide authority for modifying to sole legal custody when cooperation has broken down.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’”

Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.raw_text: Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704 (1984)
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard remains the paramount consideration.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the relationship between parental fitness and the best interests test and makes clear that, after finding unfitness, the judge must still determine the placement that best serves the children’s interests. The court remands precisely because the trial judge inadequately addressed the children’s best interests (including sibling relationships and family placement), confirming that the best interests standard remains the paramount consideration in the dispositional phase.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.relevant_excerpt: “This court has said that the ‘parental fitness’ test and the ‘best interests of the child’ test are not mutually exclusive, but rather ‘reflect different degrees of emphasis on the same factors.’ … In this case, the judge’s task was not complete once he had determined that the mother should not have custody of her children. Also, he should have addressed the various placement options which would further the children’s best interests…”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard remains the paramount consideration.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the judge’s task under G.L. c. 210, § 3 as deciding which adoption placement is in the child’s best interests and emphasizes that this is the controlling, discretionary standard. The court rejects competing presumptions (in favor of the department’s plan, the parents’ nomination, foster bonding, or sibling placement) and stresses instead that the flexible best-interests analysis governs and that all other considerations are weighed only as factors within that overarching standard.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … We…adhere to our view that in child custody cases the best interests standard mandated by G. L. c. 210, § 3, is ‘a flexible one.’”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Persistent disparagement or conduct undermining a child’s relationship with the other parent supports modification of custody.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody and visitation under a general “best interests of the child” standard and cites Felton v. Felton for the idea that undermining the custodial relationship can be relevant, but this case itself does not involve or decide a custody *modification* based on persistent disparagement or undermining behavior. The court affirms an initial award of sole custody to the mother and a reduction in the father’s visitation based on parental conflict and inability to cooperate, not on findings that one parent persistently disparaged the other so as to justify modifying a prior custody order. Thus it does not directly support the specific proposition about modification of custody for persistent disparagement.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Nor did he present any evidence showing that the wife’s perception caused ‘“deleterious effect[s]’ on the children and an ‘undermining’ of the custodial relationship,” Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 240 (1981), or that sole custody in him would be in the children’s best interests.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Persistent disparagement or conduct undermining a child’s relationship with the other parent supports modification of custody.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion directly treats a parent’s efforts to alienate the child from the other legal parent as a significant factor in the best-interests and custody analysis. The court affirms the award of primary physical custody to Hunter based in substantial part on Rose’s persistent disparagement, refusal to facilitate contact, and conduct aimed at eradicating Hunter from the child’s life, explicitly recognizing that such alienating behavior harms the child and favors placing custody with the parent who supports both relationships.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “[Rose] engag[ed] in behaviors demonstrating an attempt to alienate Jill from Hunter, such as not allowing Jill contact with Hunter until ordered to do so by the court; telling Jill that Hunter was not her parent but a ‘friend,’ and referring to Hunter as ‘the person,’ ‘someone,’ or ‘Amy’; calling Hunter a ‘dickwad’ in front of Jill… The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded… it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: When one parent acts unilaterally in major parenting decisions—such as scheduling and activities—this constitutes a material breakdown of cooperative parenting.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions only that the trial judge found "the parties are unable to communicate" and cites Rolde v. Rolde for the general idea that shared legal custody requires parental cooperation. It does not discuss unilateral decision-making about major parenting matters such as scheduling or activities, nor does it characterize such conduct as a "material breakdown" of cooperative parenting. The case instead turns on inadequate findings regarding best interests for a custody modification, so it does not establish the specific proposition claimed.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “The only finding contained in the modification judgment is that ‘the parties are unable to communicate with one another.’ Although we express no opinion in this regard, that finding, if supported by the record, might be minimally sufficient to warrant a conclusion that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties had occurred. See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981) (concluding that shared legal custody requires both parents to agree on basic issues in child rearing and to want to cooperate in making decisions for their children).”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that failure to honor visitation and co-parenting obligations, coupled with emotional manipulation of the children, can justify transferring primary or legal custody.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Kali does not discuss a parent’s failure to honor visitation or co‑parenting obligations, nor does it address emotional manipulation or alienation of the child by one parent. The custody determination turns on work schedules, caregiving history, statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and the best‑interests standard, not on interference with the other parent’s relationship. Therefore, it does not provide authority for custody transfer based on visitation interference and emotional manipulation.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: The judge’s custody award was based on his conclusion that these arrangements were in the best interests of the child. This conclusion was based, in turn, on a number of findings, including, inter alia, that the mother and the father are not able to make shared decisions relative to their daughter’s welfare, and joint legal custody would not be in Kali’s interest; that the mother provides well for Kali’s physical needs, is concerned with her health and educational issues, and is the one who ‘preoccupies herself’ with Kali’s care regarding clothing, hygiene, doctor’s appointments, and child care providers; [and] that the father works long hours…

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 1007 (2010).proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that failure to honor visitation and co-parenting obligations, coupled with emotional manipulation of the children, can justify transferring primary or legal custody.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 1007 (2010).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns interlocutory appellate procedure and waiver of interlocutory review rights in the context of an immunity-from-suit defense. It does not involve family law, visitation, co‑parenting obligations, emotional manipulation of children, or standards for transferring primary or legal custody. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition about Massachusetts custody determinations and is a mis-citation for that purpose.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 1007 (2010).relevant_excerpt: What he fails to understand, however, is that because he failed to properly pursue an interlocutory appeal when the opportunity arose previously, and because there has been no material change in the record relevant to the immunity claim since then, he cannot now secure interlocutory review of the immunity issue in a motion that appears in its essence to be nothing more than a renewal of the earlier motion to dismiss, albeit repackaged as a motion for summary judgment.

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: In exercising its discretion, the Court retains inherent authority to modify its judgments when justice and the child’s welfare require.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for modifying custody under G.L. c. 208, § 28 (material and substantial change plus best interests of the child) and the judge’s discretion in weighing factors such as children’s preferences and sibling unity. It does not discuss any separate or “inherent” authority of the court to modify its judgments outside the statutory framework or apart from a properly filed modification complaint. The case therefore does not support the specific proposition that the court retains inherent authority to modify its judgments when justice and the child’s welfare require.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’… ‘In determining whether there has been a material change in the parties’ circumstances, the probate judge must weigh the relevant circumstances; the resolution of the various factors rests within the judge’s sound discretion.’”
